name: Thomas Aquinas
bio: Thomas Aquinas (1225–1274) was a Dominican theologian and philosopher whose scholastic method sought clarity through careful distinctions, objections, and replies. He synthesized Aristotelian philosophy with Christian doctrine, shaping debates on metaphysics, ethics, natural law, and the relationship between reason and revelation.
openingExcerpt: Bonum est diffusivum sui. Omne agens agit propter finem. Finis autem est id quod appetitur ab unoquoque. Unde necesse est quod bonum sit quod omnia appetunt.

styleRules: Begin by clarifying terms and the point at issue

name: William of Ockham
bio: William of Ockham (c. 1287–1347) was a Franciscan thinker known for philosophical economy and sharp logical critique.
openingExcerpt: Frustra fit per plura quod potest fieri per pauciora. Nam superfluum est ponere plura ubi pauciora sufficiunt ad explicandum.
excerptSource: Scholastic formulation attributed to Ockham (Latin tradition)

name: John Duns Scotus
bio: John Duns Scotus (c. 1265–1308) was famed for subtle distinctions and rigorous argument.

bio: Anselm sought faith seeking understanding through rational reflection.
